STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 22, 2024
Michelle Seigo
IONIA COUNTY DHHS
920 E LINCOLN AVE,
IONIA, MI, 48846-1393
Re: License #: CP340201198
Dear Michelle Seigo:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
March 19, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of three foster care files reviewed, and one of two independent living files
reviewed (6 of 23 service plans) did not have the Updated Service Plan completed
timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/24/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 3/20/2023
4/4/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/20/2022
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
2

One of two independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation the
independent living contract was updated and provided to the youth quarterly as
required.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, stepdown
from a residential or hospital setting, return from
AWOLP, or request for change in foster home/relative
placements.
One of three foster care files reviewed, and one of two independent living files
reviewed did not have FTM's completed for all service plans as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/24/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 3/20/2023
3

FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS 1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
business days of the FTM.
Two of three foster care files reviewed, and one of two independent living files
reviewed contained FTM's without the DHS 1105 or the DHS 1105 was not
uploaded within seven business days.
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans
within 14 days of the end of the report period.
Two of three foster care files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case
service plan within 14 days as required.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement agency
foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signature pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
One of three foster care files reviewed (2 of 23 service plans) did not contain
required youth signatures on the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/24/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 3/20/2023
4/4/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/20/2022
4

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was not requested or required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency had submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
renewal inspection completed on 2/24/2023 with a corrective action plan approved
on 3/20/2023. During the review, the agency had seven violations: R 400.12213
(b) Record management, R 400.12405 (3) Change of placement, R 400.12418
(2)(b) Development of service plans, R 400.12511 (1)(a-d) Termination, FOM 722-
06B FTM, FOM 722-08D Treatment plans, and FOM 801-03 Medical passports.
Three violations were noted as repeat violations in the current inspection: R
400.12418 (2)(b) Development of service plans, FOM 722-06B FTM, and FOM
722-08D Treatment plans. One of the citations found during this year’s inspection
was a repeat from the 2023 renewal (FOM 722-06B FTM). Two of the citations
found during this year’s inspection were repeats from the past two inspections (R
400.12418 Development of service plan and FOM 722-08D Treatment plans).
During this period under review the agency noted that overall compliance was
impacted by a few staff who have struggled to adhere to the checklist protocol.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency experienced minimal difficulty in meeting
requirements during this review period. The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the
previous year’s CAP has been effective for the majority. There have been a few
staff members who struggled adhering to the checklist protocol. In addition, the
5

agency has experienced some barriers due to difficult cases and a lack of
appropriate placements and services for high needs youth.
The CA indicated the process of developing the CAP together with staff and
utilizing the checklist has been very effective. The agency has also implemented
peer auditing which has shown to be helpful in achieving overall compliance. The
Chief Administrator expressed confidence that there will be continued
improvement over the next review period.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported supervisors
meet with them regularly and coworkers are available as needed if issues arise.
Staff reported feeling supported by the agency and had no concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. Records are stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Agency Analyst identified the following safety concerns:
Safety Alert #1: Unlicensed relative caregiver home has a pool with no safety
measures in place. In addition, the home has a strong smell of cigarette smoke.
Resolution: Agency completed a home visit and verified the unlicensed relative
home has life jackets, door alarm and a fence around the pool with a lock. A safety
plan was signed by relative caregivers agreeing they will not smoke when foster
youth is present.
6

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
______3/19/2024____________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
03/22/2024
